sentences.text: Hey, what's up, guys?
So in this video, we're going to be taking a look at Daniel, who's the guy in the white here playing men's doubles.
But before we jump in, I just want to quickly say, I forgot to mention this last time, but I'm probably going to be quite negative in these videos.
And that's just because if I see you doing something right, I'm not even going to mention it and I'm just going to gloss over it.
But if I see you making a mistake, that's going to draw my attention and I'm going to be pointing that out.
That's just because pointing out mistakes, it's going to be best both for the person watching it.
So both for the person playing and then also for everyone else watching, because those are the areas that you can improve.
So just keep that in mind if it sounds like I'm being overly harsh or I'm saying you guys are terrible or whatever it is, because that's obviously not the case.
So without further Ado, let's begin.
Okay.
So first thing that stands out, super obvious, super easy to fix is that when you scissor.
So for all of these overhead shots, you should be doing a scissor kick, right?
Because it's doubles, you always have time to get behind the shuttle.
So you want to maximise the power you put into the shot.
And you do that by rotational momentum of bringing your hips through.
And that applies, by the way, even if you're doing a drop shot, right, even if you don't actually want to put power in the shop, you still always want to keep every action the same.
You want to be scissor kicking, but what you're doing.
So for the first one and the first two, actually, you're not even trying to scissor.
And then on the third shot, you do try to scissor, but you don't really.
So what I mean by that is at the start of the shot, right?
This is all correct.
This is the correct position to be in.
Your right foot is back.
Your body is essentially pointing to the side that we call this being side on.
And this is all good.
This is all great.
But what you need to do is you can almost think of it like turning your body 180 degrees.
So by the end of this, you actually want to end up with your chest facing this way, facing to the left side of the hole here.
Right.
And you want to have this same position with your feet 1ft in front of the other, but with your right foot ahead.
Right.
With your right foot in front, obviously.
But look at the position that you end up in, right.
You end up here.
You've gone 90 degrees instead of 180 deg.
So you're facing the front and your feet aside on.
You need to rotate more, either by bringing this left hip backwards more or pushing this right hip forwards more because right now you're in no man's land.
Okay?

Right here, you're lunging and your foot is pointed pretty much like instead of facing forwards, which is what you want, or maybe angled slightly, you're basically having your foot pointed to the side.
And this is bad.
This is going to lead to an injury bad.
Right.
Because what's going to happen is you're leaning forwards, you're putting your weight forwards, and there's no support, and you're just going to end up rolling your ankle.
So definitely do not do this.
Right.
Focus on pointing this toe towards the net.
And also it makes it slower for you to recover as well.
So that's definitely bad.
Don't do that.
Okay.
So here your partner lists.
And this guy plays a drop shot and you miss it.
That's fine.
That would be fine to miss a shot.
It happens to everyone.
But my problem here is take a look at focus on your feet here.
Did you catch it?
What didn't you do?
There was no splitstep, right.
You just stand there completely casual, and then it's no wonder that you can't get to the shuttle the net, because without that split step, you don't have that energy to bounce off.
Right.
So you're very slow and you're very flat footed, and you just end up getting stuck in your position, unable to get to the shuttle.
And then the other thing is, again, lunge.
Right.
You see, your foot is going completely this way.
And also this is a very shallow lunge.
So the two things that you need to change here, one, you need to split step, and then two, this lunge needs to be a deep, low lunge.
I keep talking about this because it's really important you'll cover so much more distance just by lunging lower.
Right.
And then you could still get this shuttle in one step if you lunged low enough and then obviously pointless towed towards the net as well.
Okay.
In this rally, your opponent is at the back attacking, and you're covering the net.
You're doing a pretty good job in general, and you kind of get away with it.
But there's this mistake you're making where it's like you're taking so many small jittery steps to get to and from the shuttle to cover really short distances and it's really unnecessary.
So let me find an example of what I mean.
Okay, perfect.
Right here you go into the net and then you need to take a few steps back, right?
That's completely correct.
But let's just count how many steps you take here to go from here to here.
You go.
That's completely unnecessary.
Right.
And you can see if you play back.
It looks a little odd.
And essentially it's just inefficient it's a waste of energy.
It doesn't look nice.
And in this situation, it might not be the most important, but we always want to be moving optimally because in another situation, it will.
So just take one or two steps backwards, or maybe a chassis backwards.
But whatever you do, you want it to be controlled, right?
This movement doesn't have controlled.
This looks like you're unsure of yourself, and you're taking way too many small, unnecessary steps.
Right there.
Perfect example again, right?
You play this shot, you take so many small, it's like you're scuffling backwards, right?
Just take one or two big steps or take a chassis step backwards.
Both are fine, but this kind of ballerina of stuff, scrap it.
Okay, here's something else you can improve on.
Your opponent here does a flick and sorry, your partner flicks.
The opponent here does a clear.
Right.
He's hitting it up.
And therefore, it's your job to move them here to the shuttle and attack the shuttle.
Right.
This is a really good situation for your team to be in.
But the problem here is you're really slow moving backwards, and as a result, you don't put yourself into a position where you can actually attack.
You're actually waiting for the shuttle to travel behind you.
Right.
So essentially, you're taking that shot and there's no pressure being inserted when really there should be.
And the issue here is essentially, technically your footwork, it's fine.
But it's like the complete lack of urgency and complete lack of explosiveness.
That is the big thing here, right.
As soon as you see this, you need to be pushing off explosively with the aim of getting to that shaft of high and early.
Right.
So this is more of a mental thing than a technical thing.
Just keep that in mind, especially when you have the opening to attack.
That's when you want to have that burst of explosive speed.
And the reason I point that out is because I watched the video beforehand.
Right.
And there's another example here where you actually do that.
Right?
Your opponent plays a lift, you're in this position, you see the shuttle going up here.
So you take a split step, jump to the shuttle, smash it, and you win the point.
And the key here is look how quickly and how urgent you move after you see that.
Right?
So I wouldn't be bringing this up if it's not useful to say someone move faster, because that's always true.
Anyone can move faster.
Anyone can improve on moving faster.
But you've proven that you can move at this speed.
Right.
Where you're being explosive.
So when I see you having a good opportunity like you had earlier, then I want to point it out because it shows you that you can do it, but you're just choosing not to.
So that's like a mental thing that you need to address.
Okay, so this is the final point that I want to touch upon is this rally right here.
And what you do right here is actually really important to address.
So let's just quickly rewind that.
Let's see how this progresses.
Okay.
So right here, your opponent is taking a shuttle from down low, right?
They're under pressure, they're defending.
But now let's take a look at what you're doing.
Firstly, you're not really alert.
Your partner here is alert.
You can tell he's ready to react to the shuttle.
You look like you're just kind of standing there.
You're watching the shuttle.
You're not preparing.
I think in your head you've already decided that the shuttle is going to your partner.
So you're relaxing.
But the bigger error here is the stance that you're standing in.
Right?
Now, you're in a fairly side to side stance, right.
And in doubles, you want to be doing this when you're defending Because being side to side means you can move side to side quickly.
And when you're defending, you need to cover this like side to side, mid court area.
Right.
But look at where the shuttle is.
Obviously there is no way that your opponent here can play a smash or they can put you under any pressure.
The only shot he can play that you would get is either a cross court net shot or a cross court lift, right.
So a cross court net shop will end up here and lift would end up here.
Either way, there is no chance of him attacking.
So you shouldn't be in this side to side formation.
You need to be in a front to back formation with your left leg forwards.
And what this does is if you place the net, you just take a big step with your right leg.
You lunge and you get to the net.
Right.
If he plays a cross court lift, then you Shafi back.
And just like we were talking earlier, you go back explosively and attack the shuttle.
Right.
But you're preparing for a shot that's impossible for him to play.
And look what happens after that, right?
So here he's under so much pressure.
Look how late and low he's taking the shuttle.
Right?
But because you're not doing any of those things, you're not alone and you're not in the correct position, you end up getting caught off guard.
You take the shot of super late.
Now all of a sudden what was a good opportunity?
Well, now you're the ones that are under pressure and I think you lose the rally after this.
Right.
But it's not really relevant if you lose the rally or not.
It's like when you see these things, these are like really critical errors that might not be obvious to you.
So if you optimise for these things, you're going to see a huge improvement.
